headline: Scientists discover why your middle-age metabolism is being such a jerk - Boing Boing
context: Lithograph by H.B. (John Doyle), 1839. Wellcome Collection. Public Domain
Ever wonder why your body suddenly decided to start stockpile fat like a doomsday prepper? Science finally has an answer, and it's not your late-night snacking habits.

annotations.paragraph: As reported in Science, researchers at City of Hope discovered your body is running its own underground fat-making operation right under your nose (or more accurately, right around your belly).
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces the main discovery related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Think of it like this: When you're young, your body keeps its fat-making cells on a tight leash. But hit middle age, and the fat cells go wild. It's the midlife rebellion you didn't ask for.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides an analogy to explain the scientific discovery.

annotations.paragraph: The scientists took these rowdy cells from older mice and put them in young mice. The young mice promptly developed the kind of belly that says "I've tried every diet except the one that works."
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes an experiment that supports the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: Your body apparently has this built-in self-sabotage switch that flips around the same time you start getting mail from AARP. It's like your cells hit 40 and decided, "You know what would be fun? Let's turn everything into fat!"
annotations.reason: This paragraph humorously describes the phenomenon but doesn't add new information.

annotations.paragraph: The good news? Scientists are working on ways to stop this cellular conspiracy. The bad news? Until then, your body will keep treating your waistline like a retirement savings account – constantly making deposits whether you want it to or not.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on potential future solutions.

annotations.paragraph: At least now when someone asks about your "dad bod," you can blame it on rebellious stem cells instead of those midnight pizza rolls. Though, let's be honest — it's probably both.
annotations.reason: This paragraph humorously introduces the concept of stem cells affecting metabolism, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Previously:• Your diets keep failing because your cells remember being fat, according to new study
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about previous related findings, which is relevant to the main topic.
